questions.text: Types of fibroadenosis most likely to undergo malignant change is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Proliferative Lesions and their Relative Risks for Developing Invasive Breast Cancer

questions.text: Fibroadenoma of the breast are: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fibroadenoma of breast is a solitary mobile mass which is discrete and separate from rest of the breast tissue. That is why fibroadenoma is sometimes referred to as breast mouse. Fixed diffuse mass in the breast points towards a malignant lesion.

questions.text: Regarding cystic disease of breast, which one is true? (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) BREAST CYST Occur most commonly in the last decade of reproductive life as a result of a non-integrated involution of stroma and epithelium. Clinical Features Often multiple, may be bilateral and can mimic malignancy. Typically present suddenly and cause great alarm; prompt diagnosis and drainage provides immediate relief. Diagnosis Diagnosis can be confrmed by aspiration and/or ultrasound. Treatment Aspiration for Solitary cyst: If they resolve completely, and if the fluid is not blood-stained, no further treatment is required (30% will recur and require reaspiration) Core biopsy or local excision: If there is a residual lump or if the fluid is blood-stained, for histological diagnosis (exclude cystadenocarcinoma, which is more common in elderly women) Option A is wrong as cysts are common in patients who are 40-45 years of age. Option B is wrong as excision is not done as a primary treatment, we go for aspiration of the cyst as the primary treatment. Option C is false as breast cysts do not turn into a malignant disease.

questions.text: Treatment of cystosarcoma phyllodes in a young woman: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) if we have a phyllodes tumor which is very large in size we have to go for simple mastectomy. But If the size of the tumour is small we need to go for wide local excision of the tumour with margin.

choices.text: It often metastasizes to axillary nodes
It is usually bulky and may fungate through the skin
It is treated by radical mastectomy

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is true for cystosarcoma phyllodes? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cystosarcoma phylloids is a benign tumor and it is treated by simple mastectomy. Option A is wrong as it is a benign tumour. Option B is wrong as cystosarcoma phyllodes rarely metastasizes to axillary lymph nodes. Option C is right as cystosarcoma phyllodes tends to grow to a massive size and has a bulky bossilated contour and it can cause pressure necrosis of the overlying skin and and fungate through the skin. Option D is wrong As if we have a phyllodes tumor which is very large in size we have to go for simple mastectomy. But If the size of the tumor is small we need to go for wide local excision of the tumor with margin.

questions.text: True about cystosarcoma phyllodes is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) cystosarcoma phyllodes is a large bossillated tumor of breast and it can undergo calcification and necrosis. Option B is correct as cystosarcoma phyllodes is heterogenous in consistency with solid and cystic component in it. Option C is correct as cystosarcoma phyllodes have a greater propensity for local recurrence.

choices.text: May have an underlying palpable mass

questions.text: Paget’s Disease of breast, true statements are all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is correct as in paget’s disease cells do not invade the basement membrane and hence paget’s disease is carcinoma in situ or intraductal carcinoma. Option B is correct as in case of paget’s disease one of the treatment option is mastectomy. Option C is correct as approximately half of the patients with paget’s disease have an underlying palpable mass. Option D is wrong as most of the patients with pagets disease are unilateral.

questions.text: Paget’s disease: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer as about 95% patients with pagets disease have an underlying ductal carcinoma (in situ or invasive) Option B is wrong these patients tend to have a ductal carcinoma more often and presence of lobular carcinoma is a very rare thing. Options D is wrong as in pagets disease we do not get blood stained discharge we get destruction of nipples. Blood stained discharge is a feature of ductal papilloma and breast carcinoma.

questions.text: Characteristic feature of Paget’s cell is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is the answer as Paget cells are large pale staining cells with round nuclei and large nucleoli.

choices.text: 1% associated with underlying invasive carcinoma of breast
Wedge or punch is biopsy taken from nipple for diagnosis

questions.text: All are true about Paget disease of breast except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is wrong as not just 1% but about 95% patients have an underlying ductal carcinoma (insitu or invasive). Option B is correct these tumours tend to be hormone receptor negative. Option C is correct as these patients have a poor prognosis. Option D is also correct as these patients are diagnosed by a wedge or punch biopsy taken for nipple and we typically see paget’s cells in these tumours.

questions.text: Which is not having underlying malignancy? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pagets disease of bone has no underlying malignancy, whereas pagets disease of nipple, vulva, and other regions have an underlying malignancy.

questions.text: Gynecomastia may be seen in all of the following conditions (PGI)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, C, D) (All 4 options are correct but the best possible answer here would be cryptorchidism) Gynecomastia is a condition which is common in patients who have an excess of estrogen levels In the body. Option A is klinefelter’s syndrome in this there occurs a primary testicular failure and so we get a relative oestrogen excess as compared to testosterone as testosterone levels are very low in this condition. Option B is cirrhosis of liver in this the testosterone is not metabolized in liver and it get converted to estrogen in the peripheral tissue by the action of an enzyme aromatase which is present in the adipose tissue. Option C is cryptorchidism and in this we have testis which are situated in the abdominal cavity and as leydig cells are not affected in this condition. testosterone levels are normal normal and we have normal secondary sexual characters in these patients. Option D is sex cord tumors of sertoli cells as these cells secrete estrogen so we have absolute excess of estrogen secretion in the body and so patients develop gynecomastia.

questions.text: An adolescent boy presents with bilateral prominence of breast and wants the breast to be removed. Which one of the following incisions would be ideal? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) If we have to perform an operation for gynecomastia in an adolescent boy we have to undertake subcutaneous mastectomy and for this we need to give an incision along the areolar margin so that it is cosmetically good. We do not prefer a radial, submammary or an eleptical incision in these patients.

questions.text: Treatment of choice in duct papilloma of breast is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Treatment of choice for ductal papilloma is Microdochectomy. In microdochectomy we give a tennis racket incision. Option A is simple mastectomy and that is done for lesions like phyllodes tumour and pagets disease of nipple. Option C is local wide excision and it is done for a suspected lesion of breast while performing excision biopsy or while performing a breast conservative surgery. Option D is chemotherapy and that is given for carcinoma patients and not for ductal papilloma.

questions.text: Treatment for duct ectasia: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hadfield’s operation is done for duct ectasia. In this we give a cone shaped incision and we do excision of all the major ducts involved in this condition. Option B and C are basically modified radical mastectomy and that is performed for breast carcinoma. we do not perform MRM for benign lesions like duct ectasia. Option D is radical mastectomy this was performed years back for breast carcinoma we do not perform this now a days.

questions.text: Sign seen in large duct papilloma is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In ductal papilloma we can have a blood stained nipple discharge. Option B is not the answer as no matter how big the ductal papilloma we rarely get a palpable lump in the breast tissue. Option C is skin excoriation and that is a feature of pagets disease and inflammatory breast carcinoma. Option D is lymph node enlargement and we do not get lymph node enlargement with ductal papilloma.

questions.text: A lactating female presented with breast abscess. Most common organism responsible for her mastitis and abscess formation is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The most common cause of breast abscess is Staph Aureus and it occurs in first few weeks of starting breast feeding and is transmitted by the suckling infant. Streptococcus is also a common cause of breast abscess. E.coli and anaerobes can also cause breast abscess but the most common cause is staph aureus. Typically breast abscesses are seen in staphylococcal infections and present with point tenderness, erythema, and hyperthermia. When these abscesses are related to lactation they usually occur within the first few weeks of breastfeeding. If there is progression of a staphylococcal infection, this may result in subcutaneous, subareolar, interlobular (periductal), and retromammary abscesses (unicentric or multicentric).

choices.text: Edema of skin of breast or arm
Satellite tumor nodules on skin of breast

questions.text: Haagensen’s criteria of inoperability of carcinoma include all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Haagensen’s Criteria of Inoperability 1. Extensive edema of the breast 2. Satellite nodule 3. Inflammatory carcinoma 4. Distant metastasis 5. Supraclavicular metastasis 6. A parasternal tumor, indicating spread to the internal mammary LN 7. Edema of arm

questions.text: Unilateral amastia is associated 90% of the time with absence or hypoplasia of following muscle: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Congenital absence of the breast may occur on one or both sides. • It is sometimes associated with absence of the sternal portion of the pectoralis major (Poland’s syndrome) . • It is more common in males.

choices.text: Axillary lymph node dissection is mandatory
Simple Mastectomy is gold standard of treatment

questions.text: True about leiomyosarcoma breast: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,D) Option A is wrong as Axillary lymph node dissection is not indicated. Option E is wrong as metastasis is mostly by hematogenous route. • Leiomyosarcomas are malignant tumors composed of cells showing smooth muscle features •Locally aggressive tumor and hematogenous metastasis • Palpable axillary lymphadenopathy is uncommon and when encountered usually represents reactive LNs uninvolved by metastatic disease • A clinically negative axilla in presence of large tumor may be indicative of breast sarcoma • Tumor is well circumscribed or encapsulated • Simple mastectomy is gold standard of treatment • Axillary lymph node dissection is not indicated • Postoperative radiation may be used in patient undergoing mastectomy because chest wall recurrence are observed

questions.text: Zuska 's disease seen in smoker's causes which of the following:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Periductal Mastitis (Zuska's disease) is a condition of periareolar abscess and Sinus formation. Smoking has been implicated as risk factor . Mangaged by antibiotics and incision and drainage .

questions.text: Smoking increases the risk of- 1. Duct ectasia 2. Fibroadenoma 3. Mondor’s disease 4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Duct ectasia (Zuska’s disease) is associated with smoking. Mondor’s disease is superficial thrombophlebitis of chest veins which appears like a cord-like swelling below the chest, is also associated with smoking. Breast carcinoma is also associated with smoking. Fibroadenoma is not associated with smoking.
